bestBHT.bht: Jesus, without sin himself, was unjustly associated with transgressors in his death. This does not mean that God considered him a sinner, but rather that he was portrayed as such by others. Even though some manuscripts omit this, its authenticity is affirmed elsewhere. Jesus willingly took on the sins of his people, standing in for them, while remaining holy and blameless. This fulfilled the prophecy and exemplified his selfless sacrifice for humanity.

Albert Barnes: This does not mean that he 'was' a transgressor, but simply that in dying he 'had a place' with transgressors.
Nor does it mean that God regarded him as a sinner; but that at his death, in popular estimation or by the sentence of the judge, he was 'regarded as' a transgressor.
Jesus died, the 'just' for the 'unjust,' and in his death, as well as in his life, he was 'holy, harmless, undefiled.'
Philip Schaff: This verse is omitted by the oldest manuscripts and rejected by the latest critics.
In Luke 22:37, its genuineness is undoubted.
Mark rarely quotes prophecies so directly.
John Gill: he was no transgressor of the law of God himself, but was perfectly conformable to it in his holy nature, harmless conversation, and complete obedience
he was traduced as a sinner, and charged with many foul things, none of which could be proved upon him
he stood in the room, and stead of sinners, and had all the sins of his people imputed to him, and laid upon him, with his own consent

bhtAttempts.bht: In Mark 15:28, Jesus is not portrayed as a transgressor, but rather as having a place among transgressors in his death. This does not mean that God saw Jesus as a sinner, but rather that in the eyes of the people or through the judgement of the authorities, he was regarded as one. Jesus, however, died as the just for the unjust and remained holy, harmless, and undefiled throughout his life and death. It is worth noting that some manuscripts omit this verse, but its genuineness is confirmed in Luke 22:37, and Mark rarely quotes prophecies so directly. Ultimately, Jesus, without any sin of his own, willingly took upon himself the sins of his people as a substitute, fulfilling the prophecy in Isaiah 53:12.

Jesus, although not a transgressor himself, was associated with transgressors in his death. This does not imply that God viewed him as a sinner, but rather that he was considered one by the people or the authorities. However, Jesus was always blameless and without sin. It is important to note that some manuscripts exclude this verse, but its authenticity is confirmed elsewhere. In fulfilling the prophecy of Isaiah, Jesus willingly took on the sins of his people, even though he was completely sinless.

While Jesus was seen as a transgressor in his death, he was actually without sin and perfectly obedient to God's law. Although some manuscripts omit this verse, its authenticity is confirmed elsewhere. Jesus willingly took on the sins of his people, standing in their place, while remaining holy and blameless himself. This fulfilled the prophecy in Isaiah and demonstrated his selfless sacrifice for all humanity.

Jesus, though innocent and blameless, bore the image of a transgressor in his death. It is crucial to note that this does not imply that God saw him as a sinner, but rather that he was labeled as such by the people or the authorities. Despite this, Jesus maintained his holiness, harmlessness, and complete obedience to God's law throughout his life and sacrifice. Although some manuscripts omit this passage, its authenticity can be found in another scripture, where Jesus willingly took on the sins of humanity, fulfilling the prophecy.

Jesus, without sin himself, was unjustly associated with transgressors in his death. This does not mean that God considered him a sinner, but rather that he was portrayed as such by others. Even though some manuscripts omit this, its authenticity is affirmed elsewhere. Jesus willingly took on the sins of his people, standing in for them, while remaining holy and blameless. This fulfilled the prophecy and exemplified his selfless sacrifice for humanity.
